Number TWO.
(A) Subject Report.
(B) Track Chart for ComSubPac.
Enclosures (A) and (B) covering the SECOND
War Patrol of this vessel conducted in the Luzon Strait area
during the period 6 September to 5 November, 1944, are for-
warded herewith.

- PROLOGUE
Arrived ajuro from First War Patrol.
Commenced refit.
Completed rofit, no major repairs.
Commenced training period including
torpedo approaches, firing three
torpedoos, battle surface and in-
doctrinational depth charge.
Ready for sea.

Surfaced.
Headed toward reported contact on Jap sub.
Sighted flashing light bearing 270°T on horizon. lade
ready all engines and headed toward at full speed.
Further observations showed reflections against clouds
in highly centralized area. Too diffused for search-
lights. Decided it was either lighting or bombers
hitting Hainan. Slowod and resumed patrol.
Dived on track of enemy sub reported heading north.
Surfaced. Began high speed search of area.
Sighted smoke on horizon bearing 345°T (Ship Contact #5)%;B
turned toward at full speed.
Made radar contact bearing 010°, range 6,300. Turned
away to track but during turn dropped pip on radar and
never regained contact. The 0.0.D. who had climbed to
the top of shears, reported that he could make out a
black shape under the smoke and that instead of being
over the horizon as expected he was well on this side.
Apparently ho either sighted us or picked up our radar
with a radar detector and dived. Opened to south and
made end around to his reported track. Nevor regained
contact.
Submerged. Continued search for onomy sub.
Surfaced. Patrolled probable track of enemy sub; hoaded
toward cast end of aroa.
Received report of second sub contact in our area.

100 foot and shook up up considerably; cork, paint and

broken but no major damage. He dropped two more a
couple of minutes later but those were well clear.

aboard on 144 nogacycles.

October 10 (Cont'à)
1352 I
turned out to bo ono Sinko Haru typo transport escorted
by two landing ships and a TERUTSUKI type DD, all
heading south from Bashi Channel. Pulled standard for
an hour and a half with looks overy ten minutes but
couldn't get closer than 7,700 yards.
Range 10,500; angle on bow, aftor a zig, 175 port; ship
apparently heading for Basco. Stopped closing and
waited for rango to open enough to surface and end -
around.
Sighted three Nolls (Aircraft Contact #26) heading from
Formosa toward our recent contact.
Surfaced and comienced end around.

Radar contact bearing 170°T,. distance 6 miles (Ship
Contact 10). Turned to close and track. He was a
small auxiliary schooner and turned into Dirigue Inlet
south of Cape Bojeador a few minutes after sighting.
Submerged. Patrolled north of Cape Bojeador.
Surfaced.
Submerged north of Cape Bojeador.
Sighted small fisherman (Ship Contact #11) range
13,000, bearing 183°T, hussing north coast of Luzon.
Sighted two Vals and one float plane distance 10 miles
(Aircraft Contact 30).
One plane close and turning toward us. Went deep for
20 minutes.
Sighted ship bearing 160°T, range 12,000 yards, (Ship
Contact 12), 90° starboard angle on the bow. higher
look shoved this to be the same group we saw in the
Bashi Channel, one transport, one DD. Pulled hard in
hopes that he nicht zig, or anchor at Bangui.
Close enough to Bangui to soe beach and no ship.
Turned away.
Surfaced. Cleared coast to put in charge, then headed
south for close radur search of bocch to see if ship
had anchored off Laoag.
Bright glow on horizon in direction of Luzon.
apparently our bombers are doing a through job.

Surfacod.
Sighted lifo boat which proved to be full of Jap
survivors including women hon I closed it.
Sighted two J ps on a raft. Closed and picked them up,
an army sergeant and a cor oral. They said thoir mes
wore Sato Hakaru and Terada Naoishi; that they had boon
torpedoed by a sub; and that their ship had been the
Arabia Maru.
Sighted two planes (Aircraft Contact 33). Submerged.
Surfaced.
Sighted two small vessels, thru high scope. (Ship
Contact #13) appeared to be about 500 ton coasters.
Turnod to normal approach to got ahead and investigate.
Sighted plane (Aircraft Contact #34). Submerged. He
dropped four bombs on us, to fairly far away and two
very far. Believe those two small coasters with cir
cover to be submarine trap. Turned away. On first por-
iscope look saw the plane again turning to c. zero
anglo on the bow. Went to 150 foot for an additional
half hour.
Exchanged rocognition signals with U.5.5. BRIAN
(Ship Contact 14).
Entered indoro Strait.

Surfacod. Hondod through Sibutu passage.
PR showed radar at 1,0 mogacyles strong and steady on

on the scource of this radar. Bearing showed radar to
be on northern end of Sibutu Island.
Passed Bongau Island, distance ó miles; entered Sibutu
passa c. Jap radar secured.
Sighted small boat about the size of a PT boat, (Ship
Contact #17) range 10,000 yards, heading in our:
direction. Turned amay at full speed. Apparently he
didn't sight us as he passed us and vont north through
Sibutu passage.
Sighted small boat, (Ship Contact 18), same size as a
PT boat again, distanco 9,000 yards. Headed away again,
and evaded him.
Well clear of patrol boat, completed transit of
Sibutu passage.

0645 I

1514 I
Closer look showed a small sampan. surfaced and nanned
all battle stations. Closed to see if he hero Jap,
arned, or equipped with radio.
Turned out to be native. Hodded toward Lombok Strait.
Sighted another sailing fishorman (Ship Contact 25).
1942 I
2150 I
Sighted small sailing vossel (Shi) Contact 26).
Sighted tops of Lombok Island, bearing 167°T.
Sighted sailing fisherman, range 9 milos (Ship Contact
27), submerged. He was probably the radio equipped spy
refeired to by HRAD in a recont message.
Surfaced. Hoaded through Lombok Strait at full speed.
Sighted and made radar contact on patrol vessel, (Ship
Contact #28), bearing 170°T, range 6,000 yards. Headed
slightly atra and put him abaft beam usin flank speed
while the TDC tracked him at 10 knots. fo minutes
later made out a long, low-lying ship apparently a sub
on the opposito sido of the channel. The patrol boat
soomed not so much trying to close us as trying to force
us toward the waiting sub. He fired many rod and green
flares and bursts of oxplosive ammunition from some
rapid fire weapon. However instead of turning away, I
kept the patrol boat abaft the beam and holded for the
strait. Left the patrol boat astern. Shore batteries
from south-west tip of Lombok opened fire. Iny flares
from patrol boat to direct firo; closest splash was
about 5,000 yards short. Apparently Japs wore firing
blind covering middle of channel with area fire. After
about 25 rounds firing coased.

19:
U.S.S. COBIA - Second ar Patrol - report of. (Cont'd)
C - WATHER
eather south of Formosa was rough and stormy making
extremely difficult depth control. Otherwise during the patrol
weather varied from calm to moderate, with the exception of one
rough day, October 14th, off Cape Bojeador.
D - TIDAL INFORMATION
Currents in the China Sea between Luzon Strait and Hainan
set to the west invariably during the period we were there.
Southwest of Formosa, currents tended to the northwest with an
average of a little over one knot. Off Cape Bojeador, the north
setting current from the west coast of Luzon joined the west
setting curient from the Babuyan Channel and produced a consistent
northwesterly set of from one to three knots.
E - NAVIGATIONAL AIDES
Cape Bojeador light is an excellent daytime landmark up to
ten miles from land. High peaks on Luzon, Formosa, the Batan Is-
land and the Babuyan Islands greatly facilitate radar and tangent
fixes in their vicinity. No navigational lights were seen burning
during the entire patrol.

SECOND AR PATROL
Enclosure (A)
26
27:
. U.S.S. COBIA - Second War Patrol - report of. (Cont'd)
H - ATTACK DATA
None.
No remarks.
I - MINGS
10TH FCT
DESLANT.
J - ANTI-SUBIRING SURES AND EVASION TACTICS
Planes were the principal detriment to this patrol. As we
were he ding toward Balintang Channel from the east a float plane
bombed us very accurately; later south of Formosa a big four engine
bomber bombed us again; air escorts guardod the only convoy we
sighted; and the 150 megacycle radar equipped planos south of
Formosa were a continual menace while we were there. apparently
the smaller, more maneuverable planos aro oro to be feared for
their accuracy than the large bombers. As thore were no fishing
boats or small craft found south of Formosa it is believed that
tho Japs have cloared this area of all such craft to permit blind
bombing.
The TRUTSUKI escort oncountered on October 10 and later on
Octobor 16 was ahoad of his convoy patrolling station and pinging.
The two landing craft escorts observod on October 10 were likewise
constantly changing their position in the formation.
The two coasters with air cscort encountored on October 22
were believed to constituto a sub trap. The two ships were small
and not worth an air escort unless some such purpose were held.
It is believed that the first patrol boat contacted in
Sibutu Passago was directed toward us by the shore radar which was
on us and loud in the PR. His course and speed would have inter-
cepted us had we not changed course to ovade him.
In Lombok Strait a sub - patrol boat toan was oncountered.
The patrol boat was obviously trying to force us to run close to
the Bali sido of the strait and a long, low-lying ship was sighted
there apparently a sub. The patrol boat fired flares probably
to direct shore batteries from the Lombok side which fired an area-
covering bariage all shots being well clear of us.
No anti-sub measures were found of Cape Bojeador, in Apo
East Pass, in Cuyo ast Pass, or in the Makassar Strait.
2-XTRA-
CONFIDENTLL
27
Enclosure (a.)
27
28:
U.S.S. 0031 - Second War Patrol - report of.
2-XTRA.
K - IL.JOR DEFECTS
(Cont'd)
D
BUSHIPS-
1. 24-B M.B.T. VINT - This vent bound, and failed to close by
hydraulic power. It closed very stiffly by hand and bound at the
same spot always. The cause was probably a bent operating shaft,
resulting from a close-miss aircraft bombing; but the actual cause
was impossible to diagnose due to our inability to approach the
vent in the superstructure.
It was operated by hand several times, and thoroughly greased.
Two days later it would operate hydraulically except on rare
occasions when a second motion of the hydraulic lever was necessary
to open or shut the vent.
The bell crank on this vent was an unacceptable item from .B.
which was never replaced. It is recomended that it be replaced.
2. #5 AIR BANK - By isolating the various banks after a drop in
pressure had shown an air loak in the system, #5 bank starboard side
was found leaking. stream of bubbles was seen through the peris-
cope also. The starboard side of this bank was bled down and
secured as we were unable to repair it on patrol.
3. 1 H.2. AIR COMPRESSOR - The rings in the third stage of 1
Hardy Tynes High Pressure Air Compressor broke and bound the piston.
Spare rings vero inserted to replace the broken ones. Repair was
slow due to the complexity of the design and the lack of a ring
inserting tool. Several woro broken when the piston was doing ro-
placed in the cylinder. Hore spare rings, and an inscrting tool
on the "on board" allowance instead of on the tender allowance is
recommended.
4. PITCHSTER LOG - The rodmeter of the pit-log was damaged by a
floating log and the dynamic pressure line coused pormitting water
to ontor. The lo stopped functioning.
spare roameter was inserted and lowered to the top of the
damaged one. However the old rodneter would not drop clear. It
was probably c. ntod and caught in the guide bushing at the outer
hull of the ship. is this casualty did not occur until the return
trip to the base nobody was put over the sido to investigate.
However it is highly recommended that ship be dead in the water
whenever a spare is inserted.
5. ATTACK PRISCO (92 KA 40T/1.4 HA) - Close bombs chipped the
prism of this scope causing specks on the image and impaired light
transmission. tender repair job will bo the replacement of the
prism.
6. LARK 18 TORPIDO - One Mk. 18 torpedo developed a high voltage
ground. about a cupfull of fresh water was found in the botton of
the battery compartment. All cell tops were wiped ary, water was
removed from the battery compartment, and a blower was used for an
hour to force hot air through the compartment. The ground cleared
and no further trouble was experienced.
CONFIDATL.L
28
Enclosure (1)
28
29:
• U.S.S. 0031 - Second War Patrol - report of. (Jont'd)
K - 17.JO DEFICIS (Cont'd)
BUSHI
7. HIGH VOLTAGE TRANSFOR in the SJ Radar Range Indicator. - This
transformer; T1 (KS-8571); primary: 115v .35a21"; secondary:
2.55v 1.75ª 1710v .007ª 6.4v C .6ª
2-XTRA'
The failure was a short circuit in the transformer causing
boiling out of the insulating material. It could not be repaired
due to the high voltage involved and to the construction of the
transformer.
It is urgently recommended that a spare transformer be allowed
on board as its size is small and its loss greatly affects the uso
of the vital SJ radar equipment.
0. ENGINE HOLDING DONUTS - New, long-size corner holding down
bolts on the inboard forward corner of 3 engine failed after 1450
hours. The split started at the thread and moved directly across
the bolt.
The holding down bolt at the middle of 4 main engine failed
at the end of the threads aftor 1600 hours.
9. New D.-IONIZERS - The net de-ichizors insorted to romovo coppor
and nickel ions from ba tery water bocamo badly clog od after about
3,000 gallons had passed through cach. The time for watering batter-
ies was made 4 to 5 times greater than ithout the new filters.
10. 3 INNG GOVERNOR The Woodward governor on 3 main
engine became clogged becauso unclean oil had been used in it during
the last rofit. The sliding valve was erratic on load changes.
ftor soveral flushings with clean oil it bohaved normally though
it will require dismantling and cloaning during the next rofit.
11. SJ-1 RADAR - The SJ-1 radar jammed the radio. 11 radar cases
and radar parts were grounded but the radio was still jammed when
the SJ was operated.
It is recommended that each unit of the SJ-1 be tested with
a portable frequency meter with both radar and radio operating, and
that all antonna leads be shielded.
12. .P.R. - After we wero bombed the PR showed a signal every
time the SJ motor generator was turned on. It was found to be
this local interference, but sounded in the PR like a slow sweep-
ing radar on 262 msc. This proved very difficult to trace down,
and was believed to be an enemy radar during the whole period we
were south of Formosa as the strength varied with our movements.
CONFIDLITIAL
29
Enclosure (4)
29
30:
U.S.S. COBI - Second. War Patrol - report of.
L - RADIO
(Cont'd)
NRL 1-XTRA,
Radio recoption was satisfactory. Of the old IKU frequencies
14390 was the best received during daylight, and 6380 and 9090 wore
the best received at night. Intorfor once by onomy jamming was
noted on all frequencies, being heaviest, during submarine schedules.
4525 was completely blocked. Tho jamming was in the form of CW
and consisted of intermittont koying.
Wopaco frequencies were satisfactory, though not so widely
used as to carry all the arca information.
No messages were received over the China frequencies. Several
Jap stations jammed these effectively with CW koyed continuously.
Of tho new NP submarine schedule frequencies, 9515 was jammed
by a powerful Jap commorcial station making regular voico broadcasts.
4515 was completely blocked by C keyed continuously. 16730 was
satisfactory during daylight and 6045 at night.
All the BKR frequencies from Australia were received well.
No jerming was encountered on any of these. Task Force 71 arca
frequency, 2880, could not be judged, as no nossages were received
over it.
While in aroa during early October a number of NP messages
were missed, including thro consecutivo ComSubPac serial numbers,
duo to being forced down benemy aircraft. On 4 October a S
signal as sont, asking for a repeat of NP station serial numbers
33 to 148. Manus Island received the S, but the messages wero
not retransmitted over HIKU.
One other nessago was sont from the vicinity of the aroa, and
cleared through Radio Belconnen. Our position during transmission
was off Capo Bojeador, and alert and efective Jap jamming was
encountered. Tho Jap adjusted frequency to meet ours exactly, and
jammed first by sonding the lotter "K" in the middle of each group,
later by continuous keying. Radio Belconnen nevertheless received
the message successfully.
third message was transmitted direct to VIX from the south-
castern part of the bulu Sea. No jamming was encountered.

31:
1
V.3.S. COBIA - Second War Patrol report of.
M
(Cont'd)
- NRL 1-XTRA-
RADAR
1. A-SJ. PRFORMANCE - The SJ performance was good until the time
of a major casualty which resulted in the loss of the "A" scope.
This major casualty was the burning out of the high voltage trans-
formor Tl in the Range Indicator. spare transformor was not
available so the "" scopo could not be utilized. Loss of the ""
scope made radar tracking more difficult, though not impossible,
as the PPI was kept in operation.
2. TROUBLES - (a) Indications were the scope sweeps suddenly
blurring, then spreading out and finally disappearing then there
was a strong burning smell, then fuse F5
There was no
transformer aboard that could be used to replace T1 (KS-8571).
(b) Loss of grass was the indication which traced awon to a bad
IF tube (717-) in the Xmtr-Rec. unit. Replaced V2 and operation
normal.
(c) No range pulse indication in the PPI traced to a broken video
cable, broken at the out-put of the range unit. Cable made con-
tinuous and operation normal.
(d) Regulated rectifier voltage from Reg. Rect. "B" dropped from
300v to 250v, and could not be adjusted back up at the Reg. Rect.
unit. Trouble traced to a bad 5V4G. V1 (5U4G) replaced and opera-
tion was again normal.
(e) PPI echoes varied in intensity as tho ship rolled. Troublo
traced to the last video amplifier V7 which was found to bo
microphonic. V7 (6AC7) replaced and operation was again normal.
(f) Indication of no echoes at all on PPI traced to gassy IF tube,
V207 in the Range Indicator I strip. V207(607) was replaced and
operation normal.
(6) Phantom echo before transittod pulso showed on CRT, as
indication. Trouble caused by V9 grid being raised too sharply
causing 03 to be shock excited. Trouble traced to bad condenser C9.
C9(.0068uf) replaced and oporation normal.
(h) antenna training drive misalignment caused chatter in the gears,
thus the speed of train was limited.
3. RANGES (1) With the scope in operation a ship was picked
up at 36,000 yards and tracking was started. Lobing was ineffective
beyond 22,000 yards. The ship was tracked to a range of 16,000 yards
at which time it was identified as a hospital ship.
(2) With the "A" scope out a patrol craft in Lombok Strait was
tracked from 8,200 yards to 3,700 yards then back out to approximately
8,000 yards.
LAND (1) With the "A" scope in, land (Saipan, levation 1,550 foot)
as initially seen at approximately 85,000 yards.
(2) With the scope out, land (t. Intoc, levation 2,461 feet)
on Cape Mangkalihat was initially picked up at approximately 60,000
yards.
(3) Flat Islands (Manuk - lanka Islands, levation 30 feet) were
seen at 13,000 yards, with the scope out.
These land ranges are typical examples of all land picked up by the
SJ. They also indicate that the efficiency of the SJ was recuced
by the loss of the scope; this is attributed to the inability
to tune the set to max. echo without Receiver Tuning Beat Oscillator

4. INTERFERENCE - (A) NATURE - All interforence oncountered was

jamming was encountered.

during the day. Frequencies found varied from 94 mos. to 280 mes.

PR showed a signal every time the
SJ motor generator was turned on. It was found to be this local
interference, out sounded in the PR like slow sweeping radar on
262 mes. This proved very difficult to trace down, and was believed
to be an enemy radar during the holo poriod we wero south of
Formosa as the strength varied with our movements.
While patrolling south of Formosa, in an area where radar oquip-
pod aircraft were known to be patrolling long dash radar transmissions
were picked up at 150 megacycles every Lorning at dawn. These signals
were probably the radar equipped planes signalling their return to
base from anti-sub patrol.
It is suggested that PR receivers with automatic sweeps and.
a cathode ray tube to indicate frequency and signal strength. would be
more officient than present PRs. This could be synchronized with

NRL
The only sound contact made was on a froighter in Bashi
Channel, range 14,000 yards. Turn count was 240 turns per minute
at 12 knots.
TIRUTSURI DD escort pinged on 17.4 Kcs. (Ship Contacts 8 & 12).
The QB gyro repeator failed to follow once during the run. A
cable in the sound stack in the conning tower was found to have a
poor connection at the plug. Repaired plug.
0 - DENSITY LAYERS
HYDRO
In the far western part of the area gradients as large as
fourteen degrees and beginning at approximately 100' were en-
countered. Off Hainan the temperature change on one card was
fifteen degrees from 100' to 280' and the line showed two distinct
junps (120 and 180') and a more gradual curve between them. The
boat was 6,000 pounds light at 300'.
As we moved oastward in the areas toward Bashi Channel the sharp
gradients disappeared. In the channel and its approaches there
were smaller gradients of from 2-4 degrees generally starting at
about 130' and not vory predictable in their amount of depth.
Off Cape Bojeador the gradients were again negative and moved
in steps starting at about 100' and totaling 8 or 9 degrees from
there to 300'.

PHE.LTH, FOOD AND HABITABILITY
BUMED
Health of the crew in general was excellent and sanitary
conditions of the boat were good.
1-XTRA
The following is a list of the illnesses contracted on board
during this patrol run.
-
Appendicitis, chronic. - The patient was treated as follows;B
absolute bed rest, ice packs to lower right quadrant, Morphine
Tartrate grain Stat., low SS enema which gave fair results,
nothing by mouth. For 48 hours the patient was kept packed in
ice and nothing given by mouth. Following this a light diet was
instituted and in the course of nine days patient was back to duty.
Laceration, contusion, forehead, left. This injury required two
sutures being fairly deep, but a clean laceration. Wound healed
without complications. There were no symptoms of a skull fracture.
Psychoneurosis anxiety. - Patient has been extromely nervous during
this run. Has been complaining of almost constant headaches,
dizziness, spots before the eyes, griping pains in the abdomen,
all which almost certainly aro a product of the mind. Patient has
been under treatment of Phenobarbital grains 1 and Aspirin Grains
10 daily. Recommend oxamination on entry to port.
Boils, multiple, buttox. One man has had repeated ooils which
soon to be of the infective type. He was also treated for an
abscess of the outer loft ear. Recommend blood examination on
entry to port.
Burns.
Ships Cook sustained first and second degree burns
about the face and chost while proparing the evening moal.
Patient was treated with Boric Acid ointment drossings. Codeine
grains for pain. Cause: Brussel Sprouts heating on range
exploded in his face.
Habitability was good throughout. It is highly recommended
that an additional air conditioning coil be put in the ventilation
supply duct by the aftor bulkhead of the forward battery. This
is being done on some Portsmouth boats and is very desirable.

From:

1.
SUBMARINE SQUADRON TWELVE
Mo
Care of Fleet Post Office,
San Francisco, California,
7 November 1944.
The Commander Submarine Squadron TWELVE.
The Commander-In-Chief, U.S. Fleet.
(1) The Commander Submarines SEVENTH FLEET.
(2) The Commander SEVENTH FLEET.
U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of Second War Patrol.
The second war patrol of COBIA was made in the LUZON STRAITS
area enroute MAJURO to FREMANTLE. Thirty days were spent in the area and
thirty-one more on passage.
2.
It is regretted that no contacts were made that could be
developed into attacks. In spite of lack of action, the state of morale
remains high and it is hoped that better opportunities will be found next
time.
3.
In spite of several major material defects noted on the
patrol, the general material condition is well above average. A normal
refit will be accomplished together with installation of a 40 MM. gun
and the completion of minor approved alterations.
4 "
The Commander Submarine Squadron TWELVE welcomes COBIA to
this area after a long though uneventful patrol.
J.B. GRIGGS.

5 December 1944.

1-8-45.
The Commander Submarines, SEVENTH FLEET.
The Commander in Chief, UNITED STATES FLEET.
The Commander, SEVENTH FLEET.
U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) Report of Second War
Patrol - Comment on.
AC
COBIA's Second War Patrol was conducted in LUZON
STRAIT in a coordinated Search and Attack Group composed of COBIA
and SNOOK, commanded by SNOOK's Commanding Officer.
281) 2.
COBIA had four contacts that included worthwhile
targets, but was not able to close any of them for attack. After
leaving the area COBIA was held off TARAKAN for three days to
provide Lifeguard services. No strikes materialized.
3.
Two Japanese army soldiers, survivors of the ARABIA
MARU which was torpedoed and sunk by BLUEGILL on October 18, were
picked up October 22 by COBIA enroute FREMANTLE.
4.
While patrolling on the surface in LUZON STRAIT during
daylight COBIA was closely bombed by a plane after diving. The
plane was first sighted at a range of two miles when it suddenly
appeared out of the clouds in a 70% overcast sky. SD radar
indications can be detected by planes equipped with intercept
receivers. The protection that it affords, however, under low
visibility conditions, cannot safely be ignored, particularly in
areas where anti-submarine plane activity is known to be heavy.
The award of the Submarine Combat Insignia is not
authorized for this patrol.
5.
.6.
The Free Commander welcomes COBIA's Commanding
officer, efficers and Crew to this Force. It is hoped that future
patrols in SOWESPAC will provide opportunities to again demonstrate
the fighting spirit exhibited on prior patrols.
R. W. CHRISTIE.
